definitions.definition: the top outside floor of a ship or boat

examples.text: I was the only person on deck at that time of night.
When we heard the alarm, we went up on deck.
As the storm began, everyone disappeared below deck(s).

definitions.definition: one of the floors of a ship or a bus

examples.text: We sat on the top deck of the bus.
My cabin is on deck C.

definitions.definition: a floor or platform similar to the deck of a ship

examples.text: There is an open-air **observation deck** on the building's top floor.
He fell from the upper deck of the car park.

definitions.definition: a complete set of 52 playing cards
definitions.labels: (both especially North American English)British English usually

definitions.definition: a wooden floor that is built outside the back of a house where you can sit and relax

examples.text: After dinner we sat out on the deck.

definitions.definition: a set of slides (= pages created on a computer that contain text and images) that are used to accompany a person’s presentation

examples.text: Nothing kills a presentation faster than reading off a deck of slides.

definitions.definition: a part of a sound system that records and/or plays sounds on a disc or tape
everyone helps or must help, especially in a difficult situation

examples.text: There are 30 people coming to dinner tonight, so it's all hands on deck.

definitions.definition: to prepare for an activity, event, etc. by removing anything that is not essential to it

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Middle Dutch dec ‘covering, roof, cloak’, dekken ‘to cover’. Originally denoting canvas used to make a covering (especially on a ship), the term came to mean the covering itself, later denoting a solid surface serving as roof and floor.
